questions.text: Which among the following conditions presents in infancy with cycles of cyanosis appearing with a calm, resting child and cyanosis disappearing when the child cries?
questions.solution: Infants with bilateral choanal atresia who have difficulty with mouth breathing make vigorous attempts to inspire, often suck in their lips, and develop cyanosis. Distressed children then cry (which relieves the cyanosis) and become calmer, with normal skin color, only to repeat the cycle after closing their mouths.

questions.text: A three months old HIV positive child following URTI developed sudden onset of breathlessness with intermittent expiratory wheezing. The chest X-ray shows hyperinflation. The O2 saturation was greater than 90%. The treatment of choice is?
questions.solution: URTI followed by dyspnea and expiratory wheezing in an infant is suggestive of Acute Bronchiolitis. CXR showing hyperinflation also confirms the same. Now since the child is HIV positive, Ribavirin needs to be started and hence the answer. According to CDT Pediatrics 2020, patients at risk for life-threatening RSV infections, e.g. children born at < 35 weeks, children with other severe pulmonary conditions, congenital heart disease, neuromuscular disease, or significant immunocompromise) should be considered for RSV prophylaxis therapy. High-risk patients with RSV bronchiolitis may need to be hospitalized and treated with ribavirin.

questions.text: Absolute contraindication for bag and mask ventilation is?
questions.solution: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the absolute contraindication while trachea-esophageal fistula is a relative contraindication for bag and mask ventilation. Meconium aspiration is no longer considered to be a contraindication.

choices.text: Breakdown of brown fat with adrenaline secretion

questions.text: All the following can occur in a neonate for heat production except?
questions.solution: Neonates cannot shiver. They mainly produce heat by non-shivering thermogenesis, mediated by lipolysis of brown adipose tissue.

questions.text: Primordial dwarfism implies short stature due to which of the following?
questions.solution: Primordial dwarfism refers to severe short stature seen in children with IUGR and low birth weight, who fail to show catch-up growth by 3 years of age. They can be isolated or syndromic (e.g. Russell Silver Syndrome). Impairment in IGF-1 and IGFBP-2 axis is implicated in some of these patients.

choices.text: An osmotic gap of 200 mOsm/kg rules out osmotic diarrhea

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding osmotic diarrhea in a child?
questions.solution:
Osmotic diarrhoea occurs when non- absorbed nutrients in the GI tract produce an excessive osmotic force pulling water into the bowel lumen.

  • It is often associated with intestinal mucosal damage most commonly seen in older children with lactose intolerance post infectious gastroenteritis. It will therefore stop if the child is fasted.
  • Secretory diarrhoea continues in the fasted state due to alterations in electrolyte fluxes often due to active inflammation.
  • In many cases the diarrhoea is a mixed secretory/ osmotic picture.
  • The stool osmotic gap can be calculated as follows: Stool osmolality – 2 (Stool Na + K)
  • A low osmotic gap <50mOsm/ kg suggests secretory diarrhoea, high >130mOsm/ kg suggests osmotic diarrhoea.

questions.text:
An infant is found to have rash as shown below.

Which micronutrient deficiencies can produce such a clinical picture?
questions.solution:
The findings are consistent with a diagnosis of zinc deficiency, as seen in acrodermatitis enteropathica.

  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by an inability to absorb sufficient zinc from the diet.
  • The genetic defect is in the intestinal zinc-specific transporter gene
  • Initial signs and symptoms usually occur in the 1st few months of life, often after weaning from breast milk to cow’s milk.
  • The cutaneous eruption consists of vesiculobullous, eczematous, dry, scaly, or psoriasiform skin lesions symmetrically distributed in the perioral, acral, and perineal areas and on the cheeks, knees, and elbows.

questions.text: Which among the following disorders is an example of polygenic inheritance?
questions.solution: Cleft lip/palate shows polygenic/multifactorial inheritance. Fragile X syndrome and G6PD deficiency show X linked recessive, whereas Cystic fibrosis shows Autosomal recessive inheritance.

questions.text: The IEM showing predominant cardiac involvement is?
questions.solution: Pompe disease, also referred to as GSD type II or acid maltase deficiency, is caused by a deficiency of acid α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase), an enzyme responsible for the degradation of glycogen in lysosomes. This enzyme defect results in lysosomal glycogen accumulation in multiple tissues and cell types, with cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells being the most seriously affected. The disease is characterized by accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes. Electrocardiographic findings include a high-voltage QRS complex and a shortened PR interval.

choices.text: Should be present at least for 6 months.
Behaviour must be developmentally inappropriate in two or more settings.
Should be reported by independent observers.
Must begin before 7 years of age

questions.text: Current criteria to diagnose ADHD includes all except?
questions.solution:
ADHD must begin before 12 years of age, according to DSM-5 criteria.

DSM-5 criteria for ADHD:

  • The behaviour must be developmentally inappropriate as compared to normal children of same age.
  • Must begin before 12 years.
  • Must be present for at least 6 months.
  • Must be present in 2 or more settings.
  • Must be reported as such by independent observers.
  • Must not be secondary to another disorder.

Clinical manifestations:

  • Motor restlessness and aggressive, disruptive behavior is seen more commonly in preschool children.
  • Disorganized, distractible, and lack of attention is seen more commonly in older adolescents and adults.

questions.text: Anticipation phenomenon occurs in which of the following?
questions.solution: Anticipation is a pattern of inheritance in which symptoms became manifest at earlier ages and with increasing severity as traits are passed to subsequent generations. The genetic defect in myotonic muscular dystrophy is on chromosome 19 at the 19q13 locus. It consists of an expansion of the DM gene that encodes a serine– threonine kinase (DMPK), with numerous repeats of the CTG codon. Myotonic dystrophy often exhibits a pattern of anticipation in which each successive generation has a tendency to be more severely involved than the previous generation.

choices.text: Rhizomelic shortening of the limbs is characteristic

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct regarding achondroplasia?
questions.solution:
Achondroplasia is an AD disorder. More than half of the cases are due to de novo mutations. This disorder is caused by a common point mutation in Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor 3 (FGFR3) gene. The mutations in the same gene also cause a lethal dysplasia called thanatophoric dysplasia and a relatively mild dysplasia known as hypochondroplasia.

The clinical manifestations include

  • Short stature with predominant short limbs.
  • There is rhizomelic shortening, large head, frontal bossing, depressed nasal bridge, short and broad trident shaped hands, lumbar lordosis and hypotonia, and delayed motor development.
  • Cognitive development is usually normal.

questions.text: The following non-blanching rash was seen in a child who developed septic shock and tachypnea. The child has an underlying splenic abnormality. This can be due to fulminant infection by?
questions.solution:
In fulminant meningococcal septicemia, the disease progresses rapidly over several hours from fever with nonspecific signs to septic shock characterized by prominent petechiae and purpura (purpura fulminans) with poor peripheral perfusion, tachycardia (to compensate for reduced blood volume resulting from capillary leak), increased respiratory rate (to compensate for pulmonary edema), hypotension (a late sign of shock in young children), confusion, and coma, resulting from decreased cerebral perfusion.

In this question, presence of splenic abnormality further increases the risk of capsulated bacterial infections like Neisseria meningitides.

questions.text: Most common ocular findings in congenital Zika syndrome include?
questions.solution:
In congenital Zika syndrome, macula and choroid are commonly involved. The most commonly reported macular findings include:

  • Focal pigmentary mottling
  • Chorio-retinal atrophy

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant from rural area presented with pallor, irritability, inability to move his legs, and bleeding gums. The infant is on fresh cow's milk from birth. Of the following, the MOST likely cause of his condition is deficiency of?
questions.solution: Infantile scurvy is manifested by irritability, bone tenderness with swelling, and pseudo paralysis of the legs. The disease may occur if infants are fed unsupplemented cow’s milk in the first year of life or if the diet is devoid of fruits and vegetables. Subperiosteal hemorrhage, bleeding gums and petechiae, hyperkeratosis of hair follicles, and a succession of mental changes characterize the progression of the illness. Anemia secondary to bleeding, decreased iron absorption, or abnormal folate metabolism is also seen in chronic scurvy.

questions.text: All of the following are bioactive substances or growth factors present in breast milk except?
questions.solution: Growth factors present in breast milk and their putative functions

questions.text: In order to discharge from hospital, the minimum weight gain in a severe malnutrition patient should be at least?
questions.solution:
Severely malnourished children are ready for discharge when the child:

  • Is alert and active, eating at least 120-130 kcal/kg/ day with a consistent weight gain (of at least 5 g/kg/ day
  • for 3 consecutive days) on exclusive oral feeding
  • Is receiving adequate micronutrients
  • Is free from infection
  • Has completed immunization appropriate for age
  • The caretaker has been sensitized to home care

choices.text: Hemarthroses are more common than epistaxis in this disorder
Spontaneous recovery within several weeks is expected
Platelet transfusion should be urgently performed
Prothrombin time and activated partial thromboplastin time are prolonged

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the office with petechiae and bruising on the face, chest, back, and lower extremities, which her mother noticed early this morning. The mother states that her daughter has been healthy except for a viral upper respiratory illness 2 weeks ago. Laboratory assessment reveals a platelet count of 25,000/microlitre without any splenomegaly. Which of the following statements regarding the likely diagnosis is correct?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis fits into a presentation of acute-onset ITP.

Points to note:

  • Onset of petechia 2 weeks following a viral illness
  • Platelet count showing thrombocytopenia
  • No splenomegaly.

Since there is no mucosal or life-threatening bleeding, only observation is sufficient. There is no role of platelet transfusions in acute ITP. Also note that hemarthroses are a feature of coagulation disorders, not common in platelet disorders. Platelet disorders more commonly show superficial bleeds like petechiae and epistaxis.

questions.text: Maximum concentration of dextrose that can be given through peripheral vein is?
questions.solution: The maximum concentration of dextrose that can be given through peripheral vein is 12.5%. Exceeding this concentration can cause thrombophlebitis.

questions.text: A 5 year old child presented with multiple petechiae on lower limbs and buttocks and was diagnosed as Henoch-Schoenlein purpura (HSP). Indication to use steroids will be?
questions.solution: Treatment for mild and self-limited HSP is supportive, with an emphasis on ensuring adequate hydration, nutrition, and analgesia. Corticosteroids are most often used to treat significant GI involvement or other life-threatening manifestations. Glucocorticoids such as oral prednisone (1-2 mg/kg/day), or in severe cases, intravenous (IV) methylprednisolone for 1-2 wk, followed by taper, reduce abdominal and joint pain but do not alter overall prognosis. Corticosteroids are not routinely recommended for prevention of complications such as nephritis.

choices.text: 6 cafe-au-lait macules of size 18 mm in post-pubertal male
3 Lisch nodules in iris on one side

questions.text: Which among the following is not compatible with a diagnosis of Neurofibromatosis-1?
Child builds 5 to 6 blocks at which age?
questions.solution:
Making tower using stacks of cubes:

  • 2-3 cubes: 15 months
  • 4 cubes: 18 months
  • 5-6 cubes: 21 months
  • 7 cubes: 24 months (2 years)
  • 10 cubes: 36 months (3 years)
  • Bridge of 3 cubes: 36 months (3 years)
  • Gate of 5 cubes: 48 months (4 years)

questions.text: Premature fusion of coronal, spheno-frontal and fronto-ethmoidal sutures is seen in-
questions.solution:
• Oxycephaly, also known as Turricephaly, Acrocephaly, Hypsicephaly, Oxycephalia, Steeple head, Tower head, Tower skull, High-head syndrome and Turmschadel, Oxycephaly is the most severe of the craniosynostosis.
  • Early fusion of a combination of the bilateral coronal, sagittal & sometimes lambdoid sutures.
  • Oxycephaly is a form of craniosynostosis that involves the fusion of multiple sutures.
  • The coronal, sagittal & lambdoid sutures are normally involved.
  • This fusion gives a high, conical head with sharp bossing in the region of the anterior fontanelle.

questions.text: A child came with history of fever and respiratory distress. With a suspicion of pneumonia, chest X-ray was ordered (shown below). Which of the following is most likely organism?
questions.solution:
The X-ray image shows thin-walled, air-filled cysts developing

  • Within the lung parenchyma known as 'Pneumatocele'.
  • Pneumatocele can be single emphysematous lesions but are more, often multiple, thin-walled, air-filled, cyst-like cavities.
  • Most often, they occur as a sequela to Acute pneumonia.
  • Most Commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a clinical manifestation of kernicterus?
questions.solution: Opisthotonus posturing is a feature of acute bilirubin encephalopathy but not seen in kernicterus. Chronic bilirubin encephalopathy (kernicterus) is marked by athetosis, complete or partial sensorineural deafness (auditory neuropathy), limitation of upward gaze, dental dysplasia, and sometimes, intellectual deficits.

questions.text: Horse-shoe kidneys are associated with all of the following except?
questions.solution: The lower poles of the kidneys can fuse in the midline, resulting in a horseshoe kidney; the fused portion is termed the isthmus and may be thick functioning parenchyma or a thin fibrous strand. Horseshoe kidneys occur in 1 in 400-500 births and are seen in 7% of patients with Turner syndrome. Horseshoe kidney is one of the many renal anomalies that occur in 30% of patients with Turner syndrome. Wilms tumours are four times more common in children with horseshoe kidneys than in the general population. Stone disease and hydronephrosis secondary to ureteropelvic junction obstruction are other potential late complications.

questions.text: Baggy pants appearance, absence of mental changes and loss of hair are seen in which among the following?
questions.solution: The key differentiating points between kwashiorkor and marasmus is that unlike kwashiorkor, marasmus has no pedal edema, no hair changes, no mental changes and has wrinkled face with baggy pants appearance due to loss of subcutaneous fat. Alopecia is also common in marasmus.

questions.text: A child is able to repeat a sentence of 6 syllables at what age?
questions.solution: Important language milestones

questions.text: Most common type of VSD showing spontaneous closure without treatment is?
questions.solution:
As per Nelson 21st Ed and Braunwald

  • About 80-90% of muscular VSDs and 50% of small membranous VSDs close spontaneously
  • Spontaneous closure is rare to absent in supracristal variety

questions.text: Which of the following is most common cause of acute dysentery in Indian children?
questions.solution:
• Most common cause of diarrhea in children: Viral (Rotavirus)
  • Most common bacterial cause of diarrhea in children: E. coli
  • Most common cause of dysentery in children: E. coli worldwide, Shigella dysenteriae type I in India

questions.text: Ideal delivery room temperature to be ensured during childbirth is?
questions.solution: Immediately after birth, the newborn is at high risk of hypothermia. This early hypothermia may have a detrimental effect on the health of the infant. Special care should be taken to prevent and manage hypothermia. The temperature of delivery room should be 25°C and it should be free from draft of air. The baby should be received in a pre-warmed sterile linen sheet at birth. The infant should be dried thoroughly including the head and face, and any wet linen should not be allowed to remain in contact with the infant.

questions.text: Most nasal polyps in children are due to which of the following?
questions.solution: Nasal polyps are uncommon in childhood. The two leading causes are allergy (allergic rhinitis) and cystic fibrosis. Although allergy is more common, any child with nasal polyps probably should have a sweat test, since allergic manifestations are not uncommon in children with cystic fibrosis. Benign (hemangioma, dermoid cyst) and malignant (rhabdomyosarcoma, nasal glioma) lesions are rare and can be mistaken for polyps.

questions.text: A 2 year old child presented with acute onset illness, with fever, stridor and respiratory distress. His X-ray neck is shown below. What is the appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: The clinical picture is consistent with a diagnosis of upper airway inflammatory obstruction and the lateral view radiograph shows the classic 'thumb sign'. With a diagnosis of acute epiglottitis, the child needs to be managed urgently for airway, including endotracheal intubation. Once airway is secured, IV Ceftriaxone can be started.

questions.text: False negative Sweat chloride test is seen in cystic fibrosis in all of the following except?
CHD7 gene mutations are associated with which of the following syndromes?
questions.solution:
The CHARGE syndrome (c oloboma, h eart disease, a tresia or stenosis of the choanae, retarded growth and development or central nervous system (CNS) anomalies or both, genital anomalies or hypogonadism or both, and ear anomalies or deafness.

Most (~90%) patients with CHARGE syndrome have autosomal dominant de novo mutations in the CHD7 gene, which is involved in chromatin organization.

questions.text: A child presented with diarrhea since last 1 week. He developed dehydration and low urine output. What is not true regarding AKI in this child?
questions.solution: This child is prone to develop pre-renal AKI.

questions.text: Wilson disease - All are true except?
questions.solution:
Low serum ceruloplasmin is a key feature of Wilson's disease and is often used as a screening test sometimes. Other options are true.

Also remember

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common cause of neonatal acute liver failure?
questions.solution: Gestational alloimmune liver disease (GALD) is the most common cause of acute liver failure in the neonate. In this alloimmune process, maternal immunoglobulin (Ig) G antibodies bind to fetal liver antigens and activate the terminal complement cascade resulting in hepatocyte injury and death.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with concerns about her menstrual periods. Menarche occurred at 13 years of age, and for the past 2 years, her menstrual cycles have been regular but characterized by extremely heavy bleeding lasting 7-8 days. She also has a history of frequent nose bleeds since early childhood. She denies bleeding into her joints and has been otherwise healthy. Her aPTT is otherwise normal and peripheral smear was also fine. Based on her history, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Points in favour of vWD

  • Menorrhagia
  • Mucosal bleeding, e.g. epitaxis
  • Absence of bleeding into the joints
  • Female gender
  • Normal aPTT
  • Normal peripheral smear

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was being evaluated for short stature. His growth velocity was relatively preserved. His bone age was corresponding to height age and less than that expected for chronological age. There was family history of delayed puberty in the parents. What is the likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
Points in favour of constitutional delay in growth

  • Normal growth velocity
  • Chronological age & Bone age
  • Bone age corresponding to height age
  • Family history of delayed puberty

Remember that in Familial short stature, Bone age corresponds to Chronological age and there is no delayed puberty. Other options can easily be ruled out since they show reduced growth velocity.

questions.text: What is the underlying pathophysiology in primordial short stature?
questions.solution: Primordial short stature refers to short stature seen in IUGR/SGA children who fail to show catch-up growth in terms of length or height. Reduced number of cells with defects in IGF-1 levels are responsible.

questions.text: Side effects of growth hormone therapy include all except?
questions.solution:
Side effects of GH therapy include

  • Pseudotumour cerebri
  • Gynecomastia
  • SCFE
  • Scoliosis
  • DM Type 2 only, not type 1
  • Reversible hypothyroidism

questions.text: A 3 ½ year old child presented with high fever since one week, cervical lymphadenopathy, red eyes, few erythematous papules on trunk and tongue as shown in the picture. What is the most likely complication you will anticipate in the first 7-10 days of illness?
questions.solution:
The child is fitting into the clinical spectrum of Kawasaki Disease. Note the strawberry tongue in this child.

  • Most common complication in the 1 st 7-10 days is Myocarditis.
  • Coronary artery aneurysms develop in 2 nd week onwards.

choices.text: Repeat dose of IVIG followed by steroids if needed
Double dose of IVIG and aspirin are indicated
Cyclophosphamide is the next line of management
Risk of coronary artery aneurysm is decreased by IVIG even if fever persists

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was clinically diagnosed as Kawasaki disease and started on IVIG infusion, which was given in a dose of 2 g/kg and completed over 10 hours. He was also give aspirin in a dose of 80 mg/kg/day in 4 divided doses. More than 48 hours later, the child continues to have high grade fever. Which among the following is true regarding this child?
questions.solution: Persistence of fever more than 36 hr despite using IVIG infusion in an appropriate dosage in a child with KD suggests the development of IVIG-resistant KD. In such patients, we need to repeat the dose of IVIG, followed by considering corticosteroids like Prednisolone. If still no response, anti-TNF alpha therapy needs to be considered.

questions.text: CHD7 gene mutations are associated with which of the following syndromes?
questions.solution:
The CHARGE syndrome (coloboma, heart disease, atresia or stenosis of the choanae, retarded growth and development or central nervous system (CNS) anomalies or both, genital anomalies or hypogonadism or both, and ear anomalies or deafness.

Most (~90%) patients with CHARGE syndrome have autosomal dominant de novo mutations in the CHD7 gene, which is involved in chromatin organization.

choices.text: Hemarthroses are more common than epistaxis in this disorder
Spontaneous recovery within several weeks is expected
Platelet transfusion should be urgently performed
Prothrombin time and activated partial thromboplastin time are prolonged

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the office with petechiae and bruising on the face, chest, back, and lower extremities, which her mother noticed early this morning. The mother states that her daughter has been healthy except for a viral upper respiratory illness 2 weeks ago. Laboratory assessment reveals a platelet count of 25,000/microlitre without any splenomegaly. Which of the following statements regarding the likely diagnosis is correct?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis fits into a presentation of acute-onset ITP.

Points to note:

  • Onset of petechia 2 weeks following a viral illness
  • Platelet count showing thrombocytopenia
  • No splenomegaly.

Since there is no mucosal or life-threatening bleeding, only observation is sufficient. There is no role of platelet transfusions in acute ITP. Also note that hemarthroses are a feature of coagulation disorders, not common in platelet disorders. Platelet disorders more commonly show superficial bleeds like petechiae and epistaxis.

questions.text: The following device is useful in the management of all of the following pediatric conditions except?
questions.solution:
The image shows a nebulizer machine with a face mask.

  • Nebulizer is useful to deliver salbutamol and budesonide in acute asthma
  • It can be used to deliver inhaled tobramycin and 3% hypertonic saline in cystic fibrosis.
  • According to OP Ghai 9th Ed, nebulized Ribavirin in sick children with acute bronchiolitis is indicated, for 16 hours a day, for 3-5 days.
  • However, acute epiglottitis needs airway management, especially intubation. Face masks are not tolerated in acute epiglottitis and nebulization is not a part of standard management in acute epiglottitis.

questions.text: Long nails, loose skin folds and the physical finding of white cheesy material seen in the picture, at the time of birth in a baby denotes which of the following assumptions?
questions.solution: The picture shows white, cheesy material called Vernix caseosa, which is a frequent finding in term and esp post-term babies. This, along with findings of long nails and loose skin folds are a fairly common presentation in healthy post-term babies born at or beyond 42 completed weeks of gestation.

choices.text: Single dose Vitamin A 2 lakh IU is sufficient
Vitamin A 1 Lakh IU on day 1, day 2 and then 2 weeks later
Vitamin A 2 Lakh IU on day 1, day 2 and then 2 weeks later
Vitamin A 2 Lakh IU on day 1, day 2, 2 weeks later and then 2 months later

questions.text: A 2-year-old child, weighing 7 kg, was admitted to a hospital in view of severe acute malnutrition. The child was evaluated and found to have features of xerophthalmia, with no Vitamin A drops received in the past. What dose and regimen of Vitamin A administration is recommended in this child?
questions.solution:
Vitamin A deficiency is not a frequent association with severe acute malnutrition and is an important cause of blindness caused by keratomalacia.

  • Vitamin A should therefore be given to all severely malnourished children on day 1 at 50,000 IU, 100,000 IU and 200,000 IU for infants 0-5 month, 6-12 months and children> 1 year of age unless there is definite evidence that a dose has been given in the last month.
  • In presence of xerophthalmia, the same dose should be repeated on the next day and 2 weeks later.
  • Children > 1 year but weighing <8 kg should receive half the age-related dose.
  • In presence of clinical evidence of xerophthalmia the administration of Vitamin A should be considered an emergency as the changes may progress to keratomalacia within hours.

In the given question, since the weight of child is less than 8 kg, so half the age-wise dose is needed and total 3 doses are needed in view of xerophthalmia being present, as per OP Ghai 9th Ed.

questions.text: Both the ability to run independently and social behaviour of separation anxiety in a child develop at what age?
questions.solution: A child is able to walk independently by 12-13 months of age and is able to run at 18 months, although some children may run as early as 15-16 months and some as late as 22-24 months. Separation anxiety is different from stranger anxiety and denotes anxiousness on not seeing familiar faces around. It usually develops at 18 months of age. Hence, both milestones together will be seen at 18 months, among the given options.
